meanings.definition: To finance (something) again, typically at a lower rate of interest.
meanings.sent1: I decided to refinance my home to get a better deal on my mortgage.
meanings.sent2: Homeowners often refinance their loans to save money on interest payments.
meanings.sent3: I heard a joke that the bank wanted to refinance the treehouse loan for lower acorn interest rates.
meanings.sent4: She managed to refinance her car loan just in time before the interest rates soared like a rocket.
meanings.sent5: Refinancing can be like giving your finances a fresh start, like hitting a reset button.

meanings.definition: The act of replacing an existing loan with a new one.
meanings.sent1: The refinance of my student loan helped me manage my monthly payments better.
meanings.sent2: Many people consider a refinance when they want to change the terms of their loan.
meanings.sent3: The refinance of the old loan felt like getting a shiny new toy to play with.
meanings.sent4: The refinance was like swapping out an old, worn-out puzzle piece for a brand new one.
meanings.sent5: A refinance can be a financial makeover, like giving your loan a fresh coat of paint.

meanings.definition: To obtain a new loan in order to pay off an existing loan.
meanings.sent1: I had to refinance my car to cover the remaining balance on my previous loan.
meanings.sent2: When you refinance, you essentially take out a new loan to settle the old one.
meanings.sent3: It felt like a game of financial musical chairs, where I had to refinance to stay in the game.
meanings.sent4: Refinancing was like trading in an old book for a new one with a more exciting story.
meanings.sent5: Refinancing is like hitting the refresh button on your loan, giving you a chance to start anew.
